docs.lead_paragraph: Six hundred nurses went on strike yesterday at Maimonides Medical Center, demonstrating in force outside Brooklyn's second-largest hospital in an angry picket line that reverberated with cries of strong-arm management tactics. In turn, hospital administrators hired replacement workers and accused striking nurses of sabotaging three operating rooms and a nursing station and stealing a television, microwave oven and scrub suit before walking off the job. Union officials bitterly denied the charges.

headline.main: Nurses Strike Maimonides Center In Deadlock Over Cuts in Benefits

docs.abstract: Six hundred nurses go on strike at Maimonides Medical Center, demonstrating in force outside Brooklyn's second-largest hospital in angry picket line that reverberates with cries of strong-arm management tactics; hospital administrators, in turn, hire replacement workers and accuse striking nurses of sabotaging three operating rooms and nursing station and stealing several items from hospital; New York State Nurses Assn denies accusations; new contract negotiations have stalled over issues of cuts in benefits and schedule changes; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With bipartisan support, Senator John McCain today offered a comprehensive tobacco bill that could form the basis of ground-breaking legislation meant to sharply reduce the number of Americans who smoke. The measure, containing no restrictions on private lawsuits, faced withering attacks from the cigarette manufacturers on one side and public health authorities on the other.

headline.main: SENATE IS OFFERED SWEEPING MEASURE TO FIGHT SMOKING

docs.abstract: Senate Commerce Committee chairman John McCain offers comprehensive, bipartisan tobacco bill that could form basis for ground-breaking legislation meant to sharply reduce number of Americans who smoke; says he hopes he has found middle ground that can win broad support, even though measure which contains no restrictions on private lawsuits faces withering attacks from cigarette manufacturers and public health authorities; measure would impose fee on tobacco companies to force up price of pack of cigarettes by $1.10 over next five years, penalize tobacco companies if number of teen-age smokers does not fall off to specified levels, impose strict limits on cigarette advertising and give Food and Drug Administration broad authority to regulate tobacco; main concession to industry is annual ceiling of $6.5 billion on amount cigarette manufacturers could be required to pay in civil damages; claims exceeding ceiling could be owed in subsequent years; photo (M)
docs.snippet: With bipartisan support, Senator John McCain today offered a comprehensive tobacco bill that could form the basis of ground-breaking legislation meant to sharply reduce the number of Americans who smoke.    The measure, containing no restrictions on...

A1 Infighting Rocks Khmer Rouge The remnants of Cambodia's Communist Khmer Rouge movement have turned their guns on one another, and the jungle stronghold that has withstood repeated Government offensives is now torn by factional fighting. The turmoil comes at a moment of political tension in the capital, where Prince Norodom Ranariddh is scheduled to return after fleeing a coup last July. A3

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republican leaders are drafting an election-year bill that would create new tax breaks to help people who receive no health benefits from their employers in buying health insurance. The chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, Representative Bill Archer of Texas, is leading efforts to write the legislation and is working closely with Speaker Newt Gingrich.

headline.main: HEALTH INSURANCE IS G.O.P. INITIATIVE FOR ELECTION YEAR

docs.abstract: House Republican leaders are drafting election-year bill that would create new tax breaks to help people who receive no health benefits from employers to buy health insurance; House Ways and Means Committee chairman Repr Bill Archer is spearheading efforts to write legislation and is working closely with Speaker Newt Gingrich; bill would also create new tax incentives for small business owners to buy health insurance for themselves and dependents; Republicans say price of tax package would be more than $10 billion over five years, and would be paid for with revenue from higher cigarette taxes; say they will try to impose such taxes, even if Congress fails to agree on comprehensive tobacco legislation in 1998; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the dark years when Maia Szalavitz was chasing heroin, the young red-headed New Yorker landed briefly in jail. On her release, she hurried back to her apartment and ground up some opiates that a police search had overlooked. ''And I injected them,'' she confessed to Bill Moyers. ''I mean, how irrational can you get? You've just been arrested for this stuff, and then what do you do but as soon as you go home, you do this?'' Trying to fathom such mindless compulsion set Mr. Moyers, an Emmy-award-winning journalist, on his most ambitious project yet. ''Moyers on Addiction: Close to Home'' examines why drugs and alcohol can become, in Mr. Moyers's words, ''master of your mind and tyrant of your life.'' His inquiry into the nation's persistent public health problem from the perspectives of science, treatment, prevention and sheer politics has been distilled into an engrossing five-part series that appears over three consecutive nights, starting tonight, on Channel 13 and on other public television stations.

headline.main: The Disease That Does Not Discriminate

docs.abstract: Bill Moyers discusses his family's painful struggle with son's drug addiction, subject of his new three-part PBS television documentary, Moyers on Addiction: Close to Home; interview; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Lisa Benne left her job as a seller of medical diagnostic equipment two years ago to join the Essential Data Corporation, a Stamford consulting firm, little did she expect to get breakfast at the office every morning, not to mention massages and other eclectic thank-you's, courtesy of her boss. And when Suzanne Haas needs to get her creative juices flowing at the Atlantic Group, a Norwalk-based printing and marketing firm, she takes a midday break to shoot some pool. The boss thinks it's great.

headline.main: Appetite for Talent, Fed With Flexibility

docs.abstract: Human resource professionals say biggest problem facing Connecticut companies is recruiting and retaining employees with scientific and technical skills; companies are discovering that being as creative as possible with benefits and workspace is key to attracting skilled employees; they are listening through surveys, employee committees or direct contact to learn what their staff members need to get job done and still have life outside office; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: COINCIDENTAL with two highly publicized studies that found minority groups at greater risk of certain health problems than whites, two committees of the County Board of Legislators have begun hearings to find ways to close the health gap between whites and nonwhites. In one of the studies, published in The Journal of the American Medical Association, black and Hispanic people were found to be at higher risk for Alzheimer's disease than whites. In a separate study by the Federal Centers for Disease Control, black teen-agers were found to be at more of a risk of committing suicide than any other individual group.

headline.main: County Seeks To Reduce Health Risks For Minorities

docs.abstract: Westchester County, NY, Legislators Board committees plan joint hearings on ways to cut health disparity between whites and nonwhites and improve care for blacks and other minorities; Health Comr Harold N Adel lauds hearings; cites reasons for minorities' poorer health (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I am writing in response to Dr. Elaine Fox's letter entitled ''When the Bottom Line Affects Health Care'' [Mar. 8]. United HealthCare is committed to helping people lead healthy lives, and we believe we can actually impact the bottom line by making sure members take full advantage of their benefits. We'd like to point out some of the positive steps we've taken to help our locally based managed-care members achieve good health. We send reminders to new parents to have their children immunized and write to women over 40 urging them to get a mammogram. Our outreach extends to our Medicare population and individuals with chronic diseases, advising them of the potential health risks associated with the flu and pneumonia and urging them to get immunized.

headline.main: A Health Care Provider And the Bottom Line

docs.abstract: Letter by R Channing Wheeler, president and chief executive officer of United HealthCare, on Dr Elaine Fox's March 8 letter on finances of managed health care (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The word shelter usually implies haven, but the Tinton Falls animal shelter, in Monmouth County, was anything but, according to 15 people who were banned from volunteer work there last month. In a letter and press release sent to Governor Whitman, the state Commissioner of Health and Senior Services and the Attorney General, the volunteers accuse the shelter's private, nonprofit operator, the Associated Humane Societies of New Jersey, of engaging in ''a pattern and practice of inhumane treatment that has resulted in the suffering, neglect and death of scores of dogs, cats, puppies and kittens.''

headline.main: At This Animal Shelter, It's the Humans Who Are Fighting

docs.abstract: Animal shelter in Tinton Falls, New Jersey, is embroiled in bitter dispute involving 15 former volunteers who accuse operator, Associated Human Societies, of inhumane treatment that has resulted in suffering and death of scores of animals; group sends letter to Gov Christine Whitman and other state officials; private nonprofit organization characterizes former volunteers as domineering; longtime director Lee Bernstein says charges came after he banned volunteers from everything but fund-raising, for insurance reasons; photos; map (S)
